bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, March 30, 1918

div1.p: Carter writes about daily life and a possible trip, at Gorgas' request, to Ecuador.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, March 30, 1918
div1.p:
I got down all right - after a very
hot night. & very hot it has been ever since
I went out- to Langley Field Tuesday & to Morrison
yesterday & I presume that I will leave this
place tomorrow evening or Saturday morning
-where for however I do not know. I hope for
Camp Meade - but may have “to go to Penni-
man- (on York River) opposite Williams-
burg first & possibly to Charlotte.

I went to the Commissary yesterday & got
1) a lock An Army Locker $6.30- my
trunk is broken fast mending
2) 2. cambric shirts-Olive drab @ 52 cents each
3) 4 pair socks - light woolen = 1/2 wool - @ 25 each
4) 1 " Field shoes @ 3.69:
These last I would not have had to get if
I could have found my old shoes; which
I had last year. However they are heavy
strong & big - 7-E -

I hoped it would be cooler this morning but
it isn't.

I rec'd a telegram from Dr. Gorgas yesterday
“Will you accompany Noguchi and Kendall to
Guayaqui Guayaquil to investigate
Yellow Fever. Leave June 12 - return Oct 1;”
I answered
“Fled Feel that I have ought not to leave my
present detail”
but I certainly wish I could go.l
Ea Interesting, easy, cool, work with a
higher compensation- more than double what I
am now getting. However, there the thing
is so plain that there is practically “no decision
involved”. He doesn't look at it as I do.

I am going to inspect the same work at 8.30
& it is 8.20 now - so good bye
Love to Laura Jr and all.
